Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28, the Court may modify an existing judgment regarding custody or parenting time if “the circumstances of the parties or the child have so changed that modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.”

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20 authorizes modification of custody and parenting time orders concerning children born out of wedlock upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.proposition: In **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003), the Supreme Judicial Court emphasized that stability is important, but modification is appropriate when changes in the parties’ circumstances affect the child’s welfare and best interests.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.support_reasoning: The opinion strongly emphasizes that stability and continuity in existing custodial arrangements are critically important and that unnecessary disruption of a satisfactory status quo is contrary to a child’s best interests. However, the case is not a modification case and does not state that modification is appropriate when later changes in the parties’ circumstances affect the child’s welfare; rather, it discusses how trial and temporary orders should account for stability when initially determining custody under the best-interests standard. Thus, the proposition inaccurately characterizes the decision as endorsing modification based on changed circumstances.
**Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003.relevant_excerpt: “If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child.”

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.proposition: In relocation‑related cases such as **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), the Court has recognized that significant changes in the parents’ residences and the resulting impact on the child’s daily life and welfare are central to the “best interests of the child” analysis.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the removal analysis under G.L. c. 208, § 30 as a “best interests of the child” inquiry that must consider “all the circumstances,” and then applies that standard by focusing on how the proposed relocation would change the children’s daily lives and welfare (school quality, disruption from a new home and school, impact on the child with special needs, and reduced parenting time with the father). The Court further notes that when physical custody is shared, the removal analysis turns on the effect of the relocation on the child and the impairment of existing custodial relationships. This directly supports the proposition that significant changes in the parents’ residences and their impact on the child’s daily life and welfare are central to the best‑interests analysis in relocation cases.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (200.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that in such a situation ‘cause shown’ pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 30, means a showing that removal is in the ‘best interests’ of the children taking into account all the circumstances and weighing the factors as described below. … The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, [and] that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests….”

**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas**, 39.proposition: In relocation‑related cases such as **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), and **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), the Court has recognized that significant changes in the parents’ residences and the resulting impact on the child’s daily life and welfare are central to the “best interests of the child” analysis.
**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas**, 39.support_reasoning: The opinion directly frames the removal question as a best‑interests inquiry focused on how relocation will affect the children’s lives, including their relationships, schooling, culture, and daily welfare. The court explains that determining best interests in removal cases requires evaluating whether the child’s quality and style of life may be improved by the move, the impact of curtailed contact with the noncustodial parent, and how moving (or not) will affect the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs—i.e., the effects of significant changes in residence and day‑to‑day life. This aligns with the proposition’s description of the best‑interests analysis in relocation cases like Yannas and Mason.
**Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas**, 39.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Factors that courts typically consider in assessing the child’s best interests include, among other things, the child’s emotional and developmental needs, the child’s educational needs and performance, the stability of the child’s environment, and the effect of the parenting plan on the child’s daily life. See **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001).
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses best interests in the context of removal and custody modification, but it does not lay out or synthesize a general list of best‑interest factors such as emotional and developmental needs, educational needs and performance, stability of environment, and effect of the parenting plan on daily life. Any references to the child’s development, schooling, stability, and relationships appear only in passing and are not framed as a standard set of factors. Thus, Rosenthal v. Maney is not an appropriate authority for the broad, generalized proposition stated.
**Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: Caleb was found to be a “physically and emotionally healthy” boy whose “frequent, continuing and equal interaction . . . with each parent is most beneficial to him.” “Both parents serve as equally important guides for this child’s continued healthy development.” “The Court finds the minor child’s life is enriched by each parent’s equal participation in his upbringing.” These findings would not support a decision denying removal. However, the probate judge’s findings reflect consideration of other circumstances affecting Caleb’s development and emotional well-being that, in the judge’s view, tipped the balance in favor of Caleb remaining in Massachusetts.

**Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (199.proposition: In **Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (1999), the Court held that a substantial change in circumstances that bears upon the child’s welfare justifies revisiting existing custody and visitation arrangements.
**Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion in Bouchard v. Ryan concerns Medicare/Medicaid reimbursement for qualified Medicare beneficiaries and does not involve family law, custody, visitation, or any standard for modifying such orders. The proposition about substantial changes in circumstances justifying revisiting custody and visitation arrangements is entirely unrelated to the issues decided in this case, so the citation is inaccurate for that proposition.
**Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (199.relevant_excerpt: This case concerns a dispute between the division and a physician-provider regarding the method of calculating certain deductible and coinsurance reimbursements made by the division on behalf of a class of Medicare beneficiaries known as qualified Medicare beneficiaries (QMBs). ... We conclude that the division was authorized to cap reimbursements for medical services provided to QMBs at the applicable Medicaid rate. We affirm the dismissal of the complaint.

**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that, for a modification of custody or parenting time, the moving party must demonstrate (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.: a. **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); b. **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); c. **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); d. **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); e. **Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (1999); f. **Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); g. **Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002); h. **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); i. **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); j. **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the governing standard for an initial custody determination (welfare/best interests of the child) and the appellate scope of review, but it does not articulate or apply the two‑part "material and substantial change in circumstances" plus best‑interests test for modification of an existing custody or parenting‑time judgment. The only reference to modification is a brief citation to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30 and another case, without setting out or analyzing the change‑in‑circumstances requirement. Thus, Vilakazi v. Maxie does not itself provide authority for the specific modification standard claimed.
**Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (19.relevant_excerpt: "The material facts found and reported by the judge support his action in awarding custody of the child to the father and stepmother with no rights of visitation by the mother. In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity.’ ... As to the circumstances in which orders for the custody of minor children may be subject to future modification by the court see G. L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 30, Palmer v. Palmer, 357 Mass. 764 (1970), and Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 550 (1930)."

**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that, for a modification of custody or parenting time, the moving party must demonstrate (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.: a. **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); b. **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); c. **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); d. **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); e. **Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (1999); f. **Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); g. **Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002); h. **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); i. **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); j. **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..support_reasoning: Champion v. Champion involves a post‑divorce complaint for modification, but the modification at issue concerns alimony/support, not custody or parenting time. The opinion frames the standard as requiring a demonstrated change in circumstances after the original decree, with broad discretion to the trial judge, and does not mention or apply a best‑interests‑of‑the‑child test in the modification analysis. It therefore does not provide authority for the specific two‑part standard for modification of custody/parenting time stated in the proposition.
**Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “In considering Joyce’s argument on appeal, we are mindful of our standard of review. As stated in Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26-27 (1981): ‘In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.’”

**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently held that, for a modification of custody or parenting time, the moving party must demonstrate (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the prior judgment, and (b) that the requested modification is in the best interests of the child. See, e.g.: a. **Custody of Kali**, 439 Mass. 834 (2003); b. **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177 (2006); c. **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); d. **Rosenthal v. Maney**, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); e. **Bouchard v. Ryan**, 429 Mass. 242 (1999); f. **Vilakazi v. Maxie**, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); g. **Champion v. Champion**, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002); h. **Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); i. **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); j. **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.support_reasoning: Rolde is a direct-appeal divorce case reviewing an initial custody and visitation determination, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion applies only the general ‘best interests of the child’ standard and never states that a party seeking a modification must first show a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the two‑part modification standard described in the proposition.
**Rolde v. Rolde**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 39.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… The judge did not abuse his discretion. He correctly applied these principles in deciding this question, and his conclusions are amply supported by his subsidiary findings, which are founded on the evidence.”

**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that the best interests of the child are of “paramount importance” in all custody and parenting time determinations. See **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on requiring explicit findings about the effects of domestic violence on the child when making custody decisions, but it does not articulate a general best-interests standard or describe the best interests of the child as of “paramount importance.” The term “best interests” appears in connection with a recommendation from the Gender Bias Study and statutory language, not as a broad doctrinal statement by the SJC that best interests are paramount in all custody and parenting time determinations. Thus, the case does not clearly support the specific quoted proposition.
**Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (19.relevant_excerpt: “The Appeals Court based its remand to the Probate Court on the failure of that court to make findings regarding the evidence that the father had physically abused the mother throughout the relationship and the effect of this abuse on the child. The Appeals Court gave great weight to this court’s Gender Bias Study of the Court System of Massachusetts (1989) and particularly to the recommendation in that study that, ‘The legislature and/or appellate courts should make it clear that abuse of any family member affects other family members and must be considered in determining the best interests of the child in connection with any order concerning custody.’”

**Care and Protection of Three Minors**,.raw_text: **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984)
**Care and Protection of Three Minors**,.proposition: Massachusetts case law holds that the best interests of the child are of “paramount importance” in all custody and parenting time determinations. See **Custody of Vaughn**, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); **Care and Protection of Three Minors**, 392 Mass. 704 (1984).
**Care and Protection of Three Minors**,.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the best interests of the child and emphasizes that the trial judge must consider and make findings on best-interests factors in fashioning a dispositional order. However, it does not state or characterize the best interests standard as being of “paramount importance” in custody or parenting-time determinations. The cited passage explains the relationship between the parental-fitness and best-interests tests but does not elevate best interests in the categorical way the proposition asserts.
**Care and Protection of Three Minors**,.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’… In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests…” (392 Mass. at 714-715).
